name: zstd

options.description: : # compression level (1-19, default: 3)
use DICT as Dictionary for compression or decompression
result stored into `file` (only 1 output file)
disable input and output checks. Allows overwriting existing files, input from console, output to stdout, operating on links, block devices, etc.
remove source file(s) after successful de/compression
preserve source file(s) (default)
display help/long help and exit
display Version number and exit
write to standard output (even if it is the console)
verbose mode; specify multiple times to increase verbosity
suppress warnings; specify twice to suppress errors too
forcibly display, or never display the progress counter. note: any (de)compressed output to terminal will mix with progress counter text.
forcibly display, or never display the progress counter. note: any (de)compressed output to terminal will mix with progress counter text.
operate recursively on directories
read list of files to operate upon from FILE
processed files are stored into DIR
processed files are stored into DIR respecting original directory structure
during compression, add XXH64 integrity checksum to frame (default: enabled). If specified with -d, decompressor will ignore/validate checksums in compressed frame (default: validate).
during compression, add XXH64 integrity checksum to frame (default: enabled). If specified with -d, decompressor will ignore/validate checksums in compressed frame (default: validate).
log tracing information to FILE.
All arguments after "--" are treated as files
enable levels beyond 19, up to 22 (requires more memory)
enable long distance matching with given window log (default: 27)
switch to very fast compression levels (default: 1)
dynamically adapt compression level to I/O conditions
force enable/disable usage of fast row-based matchfinder for greedy, lazy, and lazy2 strategies
force enable/disable usage of fast row-based matchfinder for greedy, lazy, and lazy2 strategies
specify the file to be used as a reference point for zstd's diff engine.
spawns # compression threads (default: 1, 0==# cores)
select size of each job (default: 0==automatic)
use a single thread for both I/O and compression (result slightly different than -T1)
use either physical cores or logical cores as default when specifying -T0 (default: physical)
compress using a rsync-friendly method (-B sets block size)
only compress files that are not already compressed
specify size of streaming input from `stdin`
optimize compression parameters for streaming input of approximately this size
generate compressed block of approximately targeted size
don't write dictID into header (dictionary compression only)
force (un)compressed literals
force (un)compressed literals
compress files to the .zst format (default)
print information about zstd compressed files
test compressed file integrity
Set a memory usage limit for decompression
sparse mode (default: enabled on file, disabled on stdout)
sparse mode (default: enabled on file, disabled on stdout)
create a dictionary from a training set of files
use the cover algorithm with optional args
use the fast cover algorithm with optional args
use the legacy algorithm with selectivity (default: 9)
DICT is dictionary name (default: dictionary)
limit dictionary to specified size (default: 112640)
force dictionary ID to specified value (default: random)
benchmark file(s), using # compression level (default: 3)
test all compression levels successively from -b# to -e# (default: 1)
minimum evaluation time in seconds (default: 3s)
cut file into independent blocks of size # (default: no block)
output one benchmark result per input file (default: consolidated result)
set process priority to real-time

version: *** zstd command line interface 64-bits v1.5.2, by Yann Collet ***
tldr:
> Compress or decompress files with Zstandard compression.
> More information: <https://github.com/facebook/zstd>.

- Compress a file into a new file with the `.zst` suffix:

`zstd {{file}}`

- Decompress a file:

`zstd -d {{file}}.zst`

- Decompress to stdout:

`zstd -dc {{file}}.zst`

- Compress a file specifying the compression level, where 1=fastest, 19=slowest and 3=default:

`zstd -{{level}} {{file}}`

- Unlock higher compression levels (up to 22) using more memory (both for compression and decompression):

`zstd --ultra -{{level}} {{file}}`
